2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), a promising biomass-derived fuel, is synthesized via the hydrodeoxygenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). This study focuses on the inherent activity of a 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst for HMF hydrodeoxygenation to DMF. The catalyst exhibited exceptional performance, achieving a remarkable DMF yield of 99.6 %. It displayed specific selectivity for C = O bond hydrogenation and CO bond cleavage in diverse substrates, producing high yield of 2-methylfuran from furfural and furfury alcohol, and high yield of toluene from benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol. In-depth characterizations unveiled valuable insights into the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst's properties, emphasizing a harmonious balance between metal and acid sites due to the interactive synergy between Pt and Fe species, enhancing hydrodeoxygenation activity. Additionally, the catalyst demonstrated satisfactory stability, maintaining a commendable DMF yield over five reaction cycles despite observed changes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Hydrodeoxygenation PtFe/C 5-hydroxymethylfurfural 2,5-dimethylfuran Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The growing demand for fuels derived from non-renewable resources has heightened amid the depletion of fossil energy. Consequently, there is a concerted effort to devise processes for producing fuels and chemicals from renewable sources, particularly biomass [1,2]. Biomass can be converted to various, including furans [3,4], alcohols [5,6], and fuels [7,8]. Among these, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) emerges as a promising biomass platform molecule, derived from the dehydration of cellulose and monosaccharides obtained from biomass [9,10]. However, the chemical instability of HMF, attributed to its highly reactive C = O and CO bonds, has prompted a focused exploration of its conversion into more stable chemicals [11]. 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) is one such chemical derived from the hydrodeoxygenation of HMF, considered a viable substitute for fossil fuels. DMF boasts exceptional combustion performance, characterized by a high energy density and octane number [12–14]. To obtain DMF from HMF through catalytic conversion, various catalysts have been developed, with a particular focus on noble metal-based catalysts. Notably, Pt, Pd, Ru, and other noble metals are commonly employed in the hydrodeoxygenation of HMF to produce DMF [15–18]. Juan et al. prepared Pt/rGO (reduced graphene oxide), achieving complete conversion of HMF and a DMF yield of 73.2 % [19]. Iriondo et al. [20] investigated the hydrodeoxygenation of HMF using noble metals such as Ru, Pt, and non-noble metal catalysts Cu in a continuous flow reactor. The study revealed that the Cu/ZrO2 exhibited superior activity for DMF, while Pt and Ru did not demonstrate high selectivity for DMF. It is noteworthy that noble metals, due to their high hydrogenation activity, may lead to excessive hydrodeoxygenation byproducts such as 2,5-dimethyltetrahydrofuran (DMTHF) and 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran (BHMTHF) (Scheme 1 ). On the other hand, non-noble metals can lead to the insufficient hydrodeoxygenation products such as 2,5–bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF), 5-methylfurfurylalcohol (5-MFA), and 5-methylfurfural (5-MF) [21]. To tailor the catalytic properties of noble catalysts, bimetallic catalysts have been introduced to enhance the selectivity of DMF from HMF. The addition of a second metal serves to tune the hydrodeoxygenation activity and acidic properties of the bimetal catalyst, thereby increasing DMF selectivity [22–25]. The incorporation of transition metal additives facilitates the formation of Lewis acid, enhancing DMF yield by adsorbing and activating hydroxyl and aldehyde groups in HMF [26–28]. Basudeb et al. incorporated Zn2+ containing Lewis acid sites to Pd/C to obtain 85 % DMF selectivity [29]. Luo et al. delved into the effects of other transition metals to the Pt metal and revealed that different metals exert distinct effects to achieve high DMF selectivity [30]. Tzeng et al. explored different carbon supports, demonstrating that high DMF yield can be achieved when Ru exists in various forms of micropores on different supports, with only BHMF obtained on non-porous supports [31]. Wang et al. developed a PtCo hollow carbon catalyst for HMF hydrodeoxygenation, obtaining a high yield of 98 % [32]. Although the bimetallic catalysts have demonstrated high activity in the preparation of DMF from HMF through hydrodeoxygenation, the extensive application in hydrodeoxygenation of other substrates has not been explored. Achieving high selectivity in DMF production from HMF hydrodeoxygenation hinges on maintaining a delicate balance between metal and acid sites, responsible for hydrogenation and oxygen removal, respectively. Despite various studies focusing on the effect of bimetal catalysts on DMF production from HMF, the underlying mechanism for tuning catalytic properties remains unclear. In this study, active carbon supported PtM (M = Ni, Co, Fe, and Mo) catalysts were synthesized for HMF hydrodeoxygenation to DMF. Among these catalysts, the PtFe/C catalyst has demonstrated the highest activity with a good balance between hydrogenation and deoxygenation activity, yielding 99.6 % DMF. Various techniques have been employed for characterizations of catalysts to understand the modifications of metal and acidic properties of the bimetal catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and preparation of catalyst Fructose, DMF, HMF, BHMF, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, and 1,4-dioxane were sourced from Macklin. PtCl6·6H2O, DMTHF, 5-MFA, 5-MF, furfural (FF), furfuryl alcohol (FFA), furan, benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol, and activated carbon (AC) were obtained from Aladdin Reagent. HNO3 was obtained from Chemical Factory of GuangZhou. Typically, 10 g AC is added to a 50 ml nitric acid solution (6 mol/l) at 80 °C for 4 h. The resulting mixture was filtered, washed with deionized water until reaching a pH of 7, and dried for 12 h to obtain the AC precursor. Then the AC support was obtained by heat treatment at 400 °C in N2 for 3 h. The PtFe/C catalyst was prepared by impregnation method. PtCl6·6H2O and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 20 ml deionized water, and a specified amount of AC support was added. The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 8 h, dried at 100 °C for 12 h, and then heat-treated at 400 °C in N2 for 3 h to obtain PtFe/C catalyst. All catalysts were reduced at 300 °C for 3 h before use. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were examined by an X’ pert Pro-Philips diffractometer, which uses Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a Thermo Fisher Scientific Escalab 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer equipped with an Al anode (Al Kα = 1846.6 eV), and all binding energies were corrected according to the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) was conducted on JEOLJEM-2010 microscope at 200 kV. H2-TPR (temperature programmed reduction of hydrogen) was test on Chem Pulsar (Quantachrome Co. Ltd). The samples were dealt with inert gas under 300 °C for 1 h then dropped to 30 °C, after that the 10 % H2/Ar mixture gas used to heat from 30 °C to 600 °C at 5 °C/min. A Nicolet 6700 infrared spectrometer (IR, Nicolet Instrument Company, Orlando, FL, USA) was used to determine the distribution of Brønsted (B) and Lewis (L) acidity in the catalysts. Prior to analysis, 50 mg sample was treated under vacuum (10–4 mmHg) at 200 °C for 0.5 h. After cooling to 50 °C, the IR spectra were recorded. Next, the sample was exposed to pyridine atmosphere for 15 min. Finally, the spectra were again recorded after vacuum desorption at 150 °C for 0.5 h, and the recorded background spectrum was subtracted. The number of Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites in the sample was analyzed by calculating the peak areas based on the absorption peaks at around ∼1545 cm−1 and ∼1450 cm−1, respectively. The actual loadings (wt%) of Pt and Fe in the catalyst was analyzed using an Agilent 7900 inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA), and the leaching of Pt and Fe after the reaction was also measured by ICP-OES by following the same procedure. NH3-TPD and metal dispersion were tested on Autochem TP-5080. The NH3-TPD test conditions were as follows: the catalyst was pretreated with inert gas at 400 °C for 1 h, then cooled to 100 °C, and purged with 8 % NH3/He gas for 1 h. After the baseline was stable, it was heated to 400 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Metal dispersion were tested on AutochemⅡ2920.It test conditions are as follows: 10 % H2/Ar gas was used to pretreat 1 h at 300 °C, followed by purging with Ar gas to 50 °C. The test was carried out under the CO pulse system. 2.3 Catalyst testing and product analysis Catalytic performance was evaluated in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a heating system and a mechanical stirrer (Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd). Firstly, the reaction mixture of 0.3 g HMF, 0.12 g catalyst, and 25 mL solvent were loaded into the autoclave reactor. Then, the reactor was sealed and flushed with hydrogen for 4 times. The reactor was pressurized with hydrogen to 3 MPa at room temperature. Finally, the pressure was 4 MPa after the temperature of reactor reached to 180 °C (ramping rate: 3 °C/min) and maintained at this temperature for 4 h under a stirring rate of 600 rpm. When the reaction was finished, the reactor was naturally cooled to room temperature with stirring. Liquid samples after the reaction were filtered using a 0.22 μm aperture filter before analysis. GC–MS (Agilent, HP-INNOWAX, Thermo Fisher Scientific TRACE 1300ISQ) was used to qualitatively analyze the product of the liquid after the reaction. The test conditions of GC–MS were as follows: 40 °C for 2 min, heated to 240 °C at 10 °C/min, and continued at 240 °C for 10 min. The conversion, yield and turnover number (TON) are defined according to the following formulae: (1) Conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − m o l e s o f H M F l e f t i n i t i a l m o l e s o f H M F ) × 100 % (2) Yield ( % ) = m o l e s o f p r o d u c t s i n i t i a l m o l e s o f H M F × 100 % (3) TON = n H M F × c o n v e r s i o n t h e n u m b e r o f s u r f a c e P t a t o m s where nHMF is the initial mol of HMF. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Texture properties of PtM/C catalysts The crystallinity of catalysts was examined through XRD characterization (Fig. 1 ). For the Pt/C catalyst, several diffraction peaks at 2θ = 39.7°, 46.2°, and 67.4° were observed, corresponding to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) planes of face-centered cubic Pt metals, respectively [32]. Both Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 crystallinity peaks were identified for the Fe/C catalyst. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 33.1°, 35.4°, 53.7°, 56.9°, and 62.5° were assigned to the (1 2 1), (−1 1 0), (1 3 2), (−1 2 0), and (1 3 0) facets of Fe2O3, while the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 29.2° and 43° were attributed to the (2 2 0) and (4 0 0) facets of Fe3O4 [33]. In the case of Pt-based bimetal catalysts, the diffraction peaks of Pt species were either minimal or absent, suggesting well-dispersed Pt behavior. For instance, a small diffraction peak for the (2 2 0) facet was observed for the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst, a slight peak for the (2 0 0) facet of Pt metal was detected for the 5Pt5Co/C catalyst, a minor peak for the (1 1 1) facet of Pt metal was seen for the 5Pt5Mo catalyst, and no diffraction peaks of Pt metal were noted for 5Pt5Ni catalysts. It suggests an inhabitation effect of forming large particles of Pt or the second metal in the bimetallic catalysts. Moreover, these observations suggest the different interactions between Pt and the second metal, leading to varying growth of Pt metal. Regarding the second metal in the bimetal catalysts, diffraction peaks were not observed for the 5Pt5Ni/C, 5Pt5Co/C, and 5Pt5Mo/C catalysts. Although peaks for Fe species were discernible, they were very small for the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst. These results suggest well-dispersed behavior of the second metal. Metal loadings were determined through ICP analysis, and the results are provided in Table S1, indicating approximately 5 wt% Pt loadings and less than 4.3 wt% for the second metal loadings. The low loadings of the second metal were lower the theoretical values probably due to losses during the preparation process. This Pt loading well with theoretical values, suggesting a good level of consistency. To assess Pt dispersions, CO pulse chemisorption was employed. Pt/C exhibited a 2.25 % Pt dispersion, while the presence of the second metal led to a significant increase in Pt dispersion. TEM snapshots and elemental mapping of the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst further illustrated the uniform dispersion of Pt and Fe species on the activated carbon (Fig. 2 ). This finding is in accordance with XRD observations. The particle size has increased compared to the Pt/C (Fig. S1), probably due to the interaction between Pt and species which led to the formation of large particles. 3.2 Acid properties of PtM/C catalysts The acid sites of catalysts play a crucial role in hydrodeoxygenation reactions. To probe the acid sites and their strength in PtM/C catalysts, NH3-TPD and Py-IR tests were conducted, and the results are presented in Fig. 3 . Due to the decomposition of the support activated carbon at high temperatures, the NH3-TPD test was conducted in the temperature range of 100–450 °C. The NH3-TPD profiles of the PtM/C catalysts (Fig. 3a) revealed a broad peak within the tested temperature range. Notably, the 5Pt5Ni/C exhibited the highest absorption peak intensity and the largest peak area, indicating the presence of the largest amount of acid sites. In contrast, 5Pt5Mo/C displayed the smallest acid amount, while 5Pt5Fe/C showed a moderate acid amount. Previous research has demonstrated that a moderate amount of acid is effective in adsorbing HMF and facilitating the cleavage of CO bonds [34]. The Py-IR profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig 3b, and the acid amounts of PtM/C catalysts are summarized in Table S1. The pyridine sorption peak at ∼1545 cm−1 is the Brønsted acid site with the adsorbed form of PyH+, while the peaks at ∼1445 and 1610 cm−1 represent the adsorption forms of PyMn+ and Py-HOM, indicating Lewis acid sites [35]. The peak at ∼1490 cm−1 is attributed to both of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [36]. Previous studies have demonstrated that Lewis acid sites can facilitate the breakage of CO bonds, leading to dehydration reactions. On the other hand, Brønsted acid sites promote the activation of carbonyl groups, favoring the preferential hydrogenation of C = O bonds [37]. However, an excess of Brønsted acid sites, especially with appropriate metal sites, may result in the hydrogenation of the furan ring. The 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst exhibits a balanced presence of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The 5Pt5Ni/C catalyst possesses more Brønsted acid sites and an appropriate amount of Lewis acid sites. In contrast, the 5Pt5Co/C catalyst shares the same Brønsted acid site quantity as 5Pt5Ni/C but displays reduced Lewis acid sites, leading to the largest B/L ratio. The 5Pt5Mo/C catalyst, on the other hand, shows almost no Brønsted acid sites but a significant number of Lewis acid sites, resulting in the lowest B/L ratio. Notably, the peaks corresponding to Lewis acid sites for 5Pt5Fe/C shifted to lower wavenumbers compared to other PtM/C catalysts, indicating the formation of Py-HOM sites and suggesting an abundance of HOM sites. In contrast, other PtM/C catalysts were enriched with Mn+ sites. This variation in acid behavior can influence the hydrodeoxygenation activity of HMF differently. The observation also indicates the beneficial role of adding transition metals in adjusting the acid strength and type of the catalyst. 3.3 Electronic properties of PtM/C catalysts The electronic properties, including reducibility and valence states of metals, play a crucial role in hydrodeoxygenation reactions by providing active hydrogenation sites. To explore the electronic properties of metals in PtM/C catalysts, H2-TPR and XPS tests were carried out. Fig. 4 shows the results of H2-TPR tests. The peak at ∼150 °C corresponds to the reduction of Pt2+ to Pt0 and was observed for all the tested catalysts. Notably, the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst showed the lowest Pt2+ reduction temperature peak with the strongest intensity among all the catalysts. This observation suggests that the interaction between Fe species and Pt species significantly enhanced the reduction of Pt2+ than the Ni, Co, and Mo species. The broad reduction peak at ∼432 °C for the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst can be attributed to the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+ [38]. In the case of the 5Pt5Ni/C catalyst, the reduction peak at ∼250 °C is associated with the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 with a weak interaction with AC support [39]. The reduced Ni species may facilitate the hydrogenation of furan ring due to the strong interaction between furan ring and Ni metal surface, as suggested by previous study [3]. For the 5Pt5Co/C catalysts, the reduction peak at ∼300 °C was classified as Co2+ reduced to Co0 [40]. This Co0 site can also contribute to the hydrogenation of the furan ring. The 5Pt5Mo/C only has a broad reduction peak of Pt2+ to Pt0. To understand the valence states of surface metals, XPS tests were performed on PtM/C catalysts, and the results are listed in Fig. 5 and Tables S2-S5. Fig. 5a shows the Pt 4f spectra of different catalysts, where the peaks at binding energies ∼71.5, ∼74.9, ∼72.8, and ∼76.4 eV were assigned to Pt0 4f7/2, Pt0 4f5/2, Pt2+ 4f7/2, and Pt2+ 4f5/2, respectively [41,42]. Comparative analysis with Pt/C revealed that the binding energies of Pt 4f in PtM/C catalysts shifted to lower values, indicating increased reduction states of Pt in bimetal catalysts. This shift suggests that the interaction between Pt and the tested second metals facilitated the reduction of Pt species [43]. Notably, the 5Pt5Fe/C showed the lowest binding energy of Pt0 4f7/2 compared to other bimetal catalysts, consistent with the H2-TPR test. Fig. 5b shows the XPS spectra of the second metals in PtM/C catalysts. For the 5Pt5Fe/C catalysts, the peaks at 706.98, 709.59 and 711.43 eV correspond to Fe0, Fe2+ and Fe3+, while the 715.9 and 719.15 eV are associated with Fe2+ and Fe3+ satellite peaks, respectively [44]. In the 5Pt5Mo/C catalyst, 232.6 eV represents the binding energy of the Mo6+ 3d5/2 [45]. Mo primarily existed in the form of MoO3, and Mo6+ is less prone to be reduced to a lower valence state, resulting in more Lewis acid sites in the catalyst [46]. For the 5Pt5Ni/C catalyst, the deconvoluted peaks at 851.6 and 869.4 eV are attributed to Ni0, the peaks at 856 and 873.8 eV are associated with Ni2+, while 861.8 and 878.9 eV are the satellite peaks of Ni2+ [34]. The form of NiO can be regarded as Lewis acid sites [47]. In the case of the 5Pt5Co/C catalyst, the peaks at 777.62 and 793.15 eV correspond to Co0 2p5/2 and 2p3/2, while 780.56 and 796.02 eV are associated with the Co2+ 2p5/2 and 2p3/2 peaks. Additionally, 783.68 and 797.55 eV belong to Co3+ 2p5/2 and 2p3/2, and 785.8 and 802.7 eV correspond to the Co2+ satellite peaks [21]. To conclude, the predominant surface Mo species in the 5Pt5Mo/C catalyst were identified as Mo6+, indicating that MoO3 was not reduced at the operating temperature, consistent with the H2-TPR results. Conversely, the surfaces of the 5Pt5Fe/C, 5Pt5Ni/C, and 5Pt5Co/C catalysts exhibited reduced metal elements, specifically Fe0, Ni0, and Co0, respectively. The presence of these reduced metal elements in the 5Pt5Fe/C, 5Pt5Ni/C, and 5Pt5Co/C catalysts contributes to varied metal states and oxygen vacancies, leading to distinct acid sites as indicated by acid analysis. Notably, Fe, Ni, and Co catalysts were found to possess more Brønsted acid sites than Mo catalysts. Furthermore, Ni0 has demonstrated hydrogenation activity, particularly in the hydrogenation of the furan ring [3], which can result in byproducts from HMF hydrodeoxygenation. In contrast, the presence of Fe0 on the surface of the 5Pt5Fe/C did not possess high hydrogenation activity and did not lead to the hydrogenation of the furan ring. 3.4 Catalyst performance and effects of the reaction conditions The reaction performance of various catalysts is summarized in the Table 1 . The reaction was performed under the conditions of 180 °C, 3 MPa H2, 4 h, 2.5 ml H2O, and 22.5 ml 1,4-dioxane with a substrate/catalyst ratio of 300 mg/120 mg. Without the presence of catalyst or with the presence of the AC support, no DMF was observed with low conversion of HMF. The use of the 5Fe/C catalyst resulted in low HMF conversion and minimal hydrogenation products, suggesting a low hydrogenation activity of Fe species. Conversely, when employing the 5Pt/C catalyst, although the selectivity to DMF was high, HMF conversion was not complete, and TON was only 8.4. The bimetal catalysts PtM/C showed a distinct scenario. The HMF conversion exceeded 93 %, with most reaching 100 %. However, the yields of DMF were < 77 % and the TONs were < 334 for the 5Pt5Mo/C, 5Pt5Ni/C, and 5Pt5Co/C catalysts (Entries 6–8, Table 1). The main byproduct for HMF hydrodeoxygenation over 5Pt5Ni/C was DMTHF, demonstrating deep hydrogenation activity primarily due to the reduced Ni° components, as revealed by the XPS analysis. For the 5Pt5Mo/C and 5Pt5Co/C catalysts, the main byproducts were BHMF, indicating a low hydrodeoxygenation activity of Pt species due to less reduced Pt species, as revealed by XPS analysis (Fig. 4a). On the other hand, the 5Pt5Fe/C showed the highest DMF yield of 99.6 % and the highest activity with a TON value of 433.7 (Entry 11, Table 1). In contrast, a simple physical mixing of 5Pt/C and 5Fe/C catalysts did not yield satisfactory DMF yield, confirming that the interaction between Pt and Fe species contributes to the increased DMF yield. Varying Pt or Fe contents in PtFe/C catalysts resulted in differing yields of DMF probably due to unbalanced metal and acid sites leading to undesirable byproducts. Therefore, the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst was chosen for the subsequent studies. The effects of solvent, water concentration, reaction temperature, H2 pressure, and reaction time on the HMF hydrodeoxygenation are summarized in Fig. 6 . The solvents GVL, 1-butanol, THF, and 1,4-dioxane were examined to understand the effect of solvent. The yield of DMF followed the order of 1,4-dioxane > THF > 1-butanol > GVL, indicating that polar aprotic solvents were favorable for DMF production. The addition of water into 1,4-dioxane solvent influenced the DMF yield (Fig. 6b). Low water concentrations in the solvent resulted in a high DMF yield, while high water concentrations decreased the DMF yield, possibly due to the low solubility of both HMF and DMF in water, leading to a reduced mass transfer rate [48]. Fig. 6c illustrates the effect of reaction temperature ranging from 120 to 220 °C on HMF hydrodeoxygenation. At temperatures below 180 °C, both HMF conversion and DMF yield decreased, with the formation of the intermediate BHMF. This observation suggests that the catalytic system required a temperature of approximately 180 °C for efficient CO bond breakage. At temperatures above 180 °C, the hydrogenation of the furan ring occurred, resulting in the production of DMTHF. The impact of hydrogen pressure on the reaction was explored (Fig. 6d). Low hydrogen pressure made it challenging to effectively promote CO bond cleavage, leading to the dominance of intermediate products such as BHMF. Increasing hydrogen pressure facilitated HMF conversion and the formation of DMF. Lastly, the reaction time was investigated (Fig. 6e). A short reaction time resulted in incomplete CO bond cleavage, with more intermediate products like BHMF and 5-MFA. With prolonged reaction time, the CO bond gradually broke, reaching a DMF yield of 99.6 % at 4 h. Further extension of the reaction time led to the production of a small amount of over-hydrogenated product DMTHF. 3.5 Recyclability The recyclability of a catalyst is a crucial parameter for potential industrial applications. Fig. 7 illustrates the reuse performance of the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst. After each reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction solvent, washed five times with 1,4-dioxane, and dried before being directly employed in the subsequent run. As depicted in Fig. 7, the HMF conversion and DMF yield gradually decreased with an increasing number of reaction cycles. In contrast, the yield of BHMF increased, possibly due to a decline in the catalyst's CO bond breaking performance caused by Fe leaching, as confirmed by ICP analysis. Nevertheless, even after five recycling tests, more than 75 % DMF yield was still achievable, indicating the catalyst's robust stability. The spent catalyst underwent characterization using XPS, XRD, and TEM to investigate the chemical valence state of surface metals, the crystal structure, and the morphology of the catalyst after the reaction (Fig. 8 ). The XPS spectra (Fig. 8d and 8e) revealed an increase in the binding energy of Pt, while the Fe0 peak disappeared after the reaction, indicating reduced reduction states and diminished hydrodeoxygenation activity. The XRD results (Fig. 8f) demonstrated a shift from high-index peaks of Pt to low-index peaks, and a decrease in the peak intensity of Fe2O3 after the reaction. ICP tests on the solution after the reaction indicated Pt leaching of 0.145 % and Fe leaching of 27.1 %. In summary, these changes, especially the leaching of Fe species, after the reaction, leading to a decline in the selectivity of HMF hydrogenation to DMF. 3.6 Substrate expansion To assess the catalytic efficacy of the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst in the hydrogenation of CO and C = O bonds, diverse substrates featuring these structures were chosen. The hydrogenation reactions of FF, FFA, benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol to 2-MF, and toluene were conducted in the presence of 5Pt5Fe/C (Table 2 ). The yields of 2-methylfuran were 86.7 % and 98.6 %, respectively, for FF and FFA substrates at 180 °C for 6 and 8 h. When benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde were employed as substrates, the yield of toluene was 93.6 % and 86.5 %, respectively, at 250 °C for 8 h. These results indicate that the catalyst exhibits robust catalytic performance across various substrates, displaying distinctive selectivity for the hydrogenation of C = O bonds and the cleavage of CO bonds. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, the synthesis of a 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst for HMF hydrogenation yielded an impressive 99.6 % DMF yield. The catalyst displayed notable selectivity for C = O bond hydrogenation and CO bond cleavage, exemplified in various substrates such as FF, FFA, benzaldehyde, and benzyl alcohol, leading to 2-methylfuran and toluene production. Comprehensive characterizations of the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst provided insights into its structural properties and catalytic behavior. The catalyst demonstrated a favorable balance between metal and acid sites, attributed to the synergistic interaction between Pt and Fe species, resulting in robust hydrodeoxygenation activity. Exploration of different solvents, reaction time, and temperature highlighted their effects on the catalytic process. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited satisfactory stability, maintaining a commendable DMF yield after five cycles, despite observed changes. coredata.dc:description: 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), a promising biomass-derived fuel, is synthesized via the hydrodeoxygenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). This study focuses on the inherent activity of a 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst for HMF hydrodeoxygenation to DMF. The catalyst exhibited exceptional performance, achieving a remarkable DMF yield of 99.6 %. It displayed specific selectivity for C = O bond hydrogenation and CO bond cleavage in diverse substrates, producing high yield of 2-methylfuran from furfural and furfury alcohol, and high yield of toluene from benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol. In-depth characterizations unveiled valuable insights into the 5Pt5Fe/C catalyst's properties, emphasizing a harmonious balance between metal and acid sites due to the interactive synergy between Pt and Fe species, enhancing hydrodeoxygenation activity. Additionally, the catalyst demonstrated satisfactory stability, maintaining a commendable DMF yield over five reaction cycles despite observed changes.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrodeoxygenation of 5-hydromethylfurfural to 2,5-dimethylfuran over PtFe/C catalyst
